image.altText: A map of Australia electorates divided between orange and purple.

items.synopsis: The rules that determine how the Voice referendum will be run were written more than 100 years ago.

title.children: In referendums, not all votes are created equal

image.altText: Two volunteers wearing Yes and No campaign shirts stand next to each other with their faces cropped out.

items.synopsis: As an Aboriginal person, it feels impossible to digest the freight train of messages coming towards us each day. Most of it is about us, without us, writes Bridget Brennan.

title.children: The Voice debate has put the worst of Australia on display. Indigenous people deserve better

image.altText: Anthony Albanese at a press conference, a close up of him in a pair of round glasses.

items.synopsis: Two-hundred-and-twenty Australians are set to leave Israel on a Qantas flight from Tel Aviv early tomorrow morning as the Israel-Gaza war escalates.

title.children: Adelaide family of four among 19 Australians trying to leave Gaza

image.altText: a senior police man standing outdoors and talking to the media

items.synopsis: Police will be able to search protesters and require identification ahead of a planned pro-Palestinian rally in Sydney's CBD.

title.children: Pro-Palestinian protestors say 'draconian' police powers won't stop Sydney rally

image.altText: A man sits leaning against a wall, looking wistfully past camera

items.synopsis: When Israeli air strikes began near their home, Hana' Nayem and her family decided to flee on foot. She and more than 20 relatives have taken shelter elsewhere, but right now, nowhere in Gaza is safe.

title.children: No power, no food, and no end in sight: This is life for millions of Palestinians trapped inside Gaza

image.altText: Aboriginal people in a NT community - generic image

items.synopsis: Catch up on the day's updates from our coverage of the Voice to Parliament campaign on Friday, October 13.

title.children: 'People don't live long enough to become geriatric': Physician calls for Yes vote — As it happened

image.altText: Greyhound dogs racing on a track in Sydney.

items.synopsis: The state government is "considering" a request from TasRacing for more funding, after the cost of its new greyhound and harness racing project in Tasmania's north-west blew out to more than double the original estimate.

title.children: Tasracing asks government to double funding for new track as costs blow out to $38m

image.altText: Jim Everett

items.synopsis: Aboriginal activist Jimmy Everett-Puralia Meenamatta doesn't believe the Voice would result in meaningful change for First Nations people. Instead, he'd prefer to see a treaty.

title.children: Why I'd prefer treaty instead of the Voice to Parliament

image.altText: Meg Southcombe on The Drum panel.

items.synopsis: In a 56-second clip, student teacher and mental health advocate Meg Southcombe sums up why educators need more respect. Her words are resonating across the internet.

title.children: 'I'll yell it louder for the people at the back': Meg called for more respect for teachers. Her words have struck a nerve

image.altText: A hand placing a ballot in a voting box.

items.synopsis: As the date of the Voice to Parliament referendum nears, misinformation about the voting process has intensified. Here are some of the biggest debunked claims.

title.children: Don't do this to your ballot paper if you want your vote to count in the referendum

image.altText: Smoke is coming from Gaza following Israeli strikes.

items.synopsis: Israel tells civilians living in northern Gaza to head south, warning them the military will operate "significantly" in Gaza City in the coming days.

title.children: Israel Defense Forces warn over 1 million Gazans to relocate to the south — as it happened

image.altText: Thick black and grey smoke rises above multistorey buildings following an airstrike.

items.synopsis: Fears are widening that the Israel-Gaza conflict could spread further and create more volatility for investors and the global economy, writes Nassim Khadem.

title.children: As Israel's war against Hamas escalates, US sends a warning to Iran, raising fears of a recession

image.altText: A screenshot of Australia batter Marcus Stoinis's review of a caught behind decision during the Cricket World Cup.

items.synopsis: The dismissal of Marcus Stoinis likely had little impact on Australia's 134-run loss to South Africa at the World Cup, but Marnus Labuschagne is hoping for some clarity to avoid similar confusion going forward.

title.children: 'The umpires didn't know what was going on': DRS confusion reigns in Australia's World Cup thumping

image.altText: Composite image of Jade Gresham, Xavier Duursma and Shane McAdam.

items.synopsis: Jade Gresham's move to Essendon is competed hours before the free agency deadline, while Jack Gunston shocks Brisbane by requesting a move back to Hawthorn.

title.children: Bombers land big free agency fish, triple-premiership forward requests trade to Hawks

image.altText: The hand of a man in a suit checking the ASX website on his phone at the ASX.

items.synopsis: The latest data out of the US shows inflation is sticking around, which is leading investors to worry that regulators there will start raising rates again soon. Meanwhile, experts warn that if the Israel-Gaza war escalates, it has the "potential to certainly derail markets". See how the day unfolded on our markets and economics blog.

title.children: Inflation data reignites interest rate fears on Wall Street and ASX, while Israel-Gaza war sparks recession fears — as it happened

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair and a black top looks into the camera.

items.synopsis: Despite the prominence of pro-Voice views in mainstream and social media, researchers tracking polling found the Yes campaign failed to sway voters.

title.children: No campaign outperforming Yes on social media, researchers say

image.altText: A view from the back of a large concert hall showing a full audience and an orchestra on stage.

items.synopsis: Heart rate, breathing and skin conductance demonstrate how listening to live classical music together moves audiences.

title.children: 'The body is always involved':  How classical music concerts synchronise an audience's heartbeats

image.altText: Two boys swim in a waterhole in an Aboriginal community near Alice Springs

items.synopsis: The No campaign argues the National Indigenous Australians Agency, a government agency which funds programs for First Nations people, is an existing voice to parliament, but is that right?

title.children: The No campaign says this little-known agency is an existing voice to parliament. Here's why it's not

image.altText: Two young people sit on the ground in handcuffs while a third is laying down while being arrested. Police stand nearby.

items.synopsis: Queensland is frequently portrayed as being in the grips of a worsening crime, epidemic despite data suggesting otherwise. But a trip down memory lane reveals the media has been reporting a similar sentiment for nearly 200 years.

title.children: Queensland media blaming crime on 'spoilt children' or 'weak judges' for nearly two centuries

image.altText: Bright yellow orange sky with Uluru in foreground.

items.synopsis: The two New South Wales men, who claim to be sovereign citizens, were fined almost $9,000 each for entering and vandalising the prohibited site.

title.children: 'No shame': Pair found guilty of using oily handprints to damage sacred Uluru cave art

image.altText: Tracy Adams wears a blue top

items.synopsis: A national summit addressing the housing crisis has heard successive governments are to blame for getting Australians to this "flash point", and it could take up to 20 years to fix the problem.

title.children: Tracy is using her super to subsidise her rent. When it runs out, the 62-year-old 'may be homeless again'

image.altText: A view of a narrow underground tunnel.

items.synopsis: An Israeli invasion of Gaza will face an enemy that has built a formidable armoury, dug a vast tunnel network to evade attackers and shown in past ground wars it can exact a heavier toll on Israeli troops each time.

title.children: To defeat Hamas, the Israeli military will likely have to conquer tunnels they call the 'Gaza metro'

image.altText: Four Israeli tanks drive in a line, with small Israeli flags flying from them.

items.synopsis: Israel's army says its campaign against Hamas is aimed at "taking out" the terror group's senior leadership including top government officials.

title.children: Israel prepares for 'ground manoeuvre' against Hamas as Blinken urges restraint

image.altText: A gold and silver to pound coin is held up by a hand in a white glove.

items.synopsis: The unveiling of eight new definitive coins marks the final chapter of King Charles III's transition onto British coinage.

title.children: UK's Royal Mint unveils new coin designs inspired by King Charles's love for the environment

image.altText: A purple-blue backlit desk featuring multiple people playing games on keyboards.

items.synopsis: What are the climate consequences of developing video games? When an independent studio made its sixth game, it decided to find out.

title.children: 'No video games on a dead planet': New report reveals carbon cost of game development

image.altText: A group of people hug on a road

items.synopsis: Roger Cook is condemned for describing a controversial youth detention unit in an adult jail as a "necessary evil", as a 16-year-old boy remains in a critical but stable condition in hospital.

title.children: 'A disgusting comment': WA premier under fire for response to incident at Casuarina Prison as boy fights for life

image.altText: A grahpic of coloured question marks surrounding a black and white photo of parliament house.

items.synopsis: One of Australia's leading constitutional law experts believes the Voice referendum could be the last time Australians vote to change the constitution, after more than 12 months of campaigning from both sides of politics.

title.children: Constitutional expert believes Voice vote could be the last referendum held in Australia

image.altText: A dinner setting in front of Uluru at dusk

items.synopsis: Two senior business executives have appeared in court, accused of an embezzlement scheme against luxury tourism company Voyages that went undetected for months.

title.children: Business executives accused of defrauding Indigenous tourism company of almost $500,000

image.altText: young women in formal dresses laughing

items.synopsis: Gowns and suits have brought glitz and glamour to the remote Indigenous community of Aurukun on the Cape York Peninsula for the town's second-ever NAIDOC ball.

title.children: Teenagers in remote Indigenous community enjoy a chance to get dressed to the nines

image.altText: A blister pack of the antibiotic doxycycline, which is used to treat a range of conditions from acne to cholera.

items.synopsis: Australia's leading sexual health experts say taking a drug known as "doxy-PEP" after unprotected sex could help curb rising rates of syphilis, but there's a big catch associated with antibiotic use.

title.children: There's a lot of talk about doxy-PEP right now. This is how the post-sex antibiotic works

image.altText: A man in a suit on a football pitch looks argumentative about something.

items.synopsis: Graham Arnold criticises politicians over a lack of soccer funding, as Australia prepares to take on England in a friendly clash at Wembley.

title.children: 'It's only played in one country': Socceroos coach takes aim at AFL and Albanese over funding for Australian soccer

image.altText: A boxer sitting on the shoulders of another man in a boxing ring.

items.synopsis: A new generation of Indigenous fighters is lacing up the gloves and looking to emulate the achievements of their elders who broke down barriers in the sport.

title.children: The new generation of Aboriginal boxers fighting for a piece of sporting history

image.altText: Turtle swimming with moss on head.

items.synopsis: Home to fish that have been around since the time of dinosaurs, Queensland's mighty Mary River is facing a worrying dry spell that some believe could lead to fish kills.

title.children: Bum-breathing turtles and prehistoric fish live in this waterway. But after flooding last year, it's starting to dry up

image.altText: Ripe fresh fruit, lemons, green and red apples in a shop

items.synopsis: Retail fruit prices have barely changed in two decades, exports have dropped to about two per cent of the nation's crop and producers are fleeing the industry, new data from a NSW Farmers Association survey reveals.

title.children: Almost 85pc of Australians regularly buy apples. So why are farmers exiting the industry in droves?

image.altText: A porcupine using its spikes to defend itself against a leopard

items.synopsis: An image of a mysterious, shimmering golden horseshoe crab, one of almost 50,000 entries from 95 countries, takes first place in the Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition.

title.children: Fighting goats and a hippo nursery: The winning images from the Wildlife Photographer of the Year competition
